bestBHT.bht: The mention of the book of Moses and the place concerning the Bush in this reference is an allusion to the renowned account of God speaking to Moses from the burning bush. The interpretation of the phrase in/at the bush may vary, but the structure of the text suggests it pertains to the specific section of Moses' history that revolves around the burning bush incident. This section is significant as it affirms God's identity as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

Henry Alford: The words may in the original mean either, ‘in the chapter containing the history of God appearing in the Bush,’ or, ‘when he was at the Bush.’" (quote 1)
The former is the more probable, on account of the construction of the verse in our text." (quote 2)
In Luke, if we had his account alone, the other rendering might be admissible, ‘Moses testified, at the Bush:’ but this will not answer in our text." (quote 3)
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: And as touching the dead, that they rise: have ye not read in the book of Moses—"even Moses"—whom they had just quoted for the purpose of entangling Him."

how in the bush God spake unto him—either 'at the bush,' as the same expression is rendered in Luke 20:37, that is, when he was there; or 'in the [section of his history regarding the] bush.' The structure of our verse suggests the latter sense, which is not unusual.
saying, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?
Marvin Vincent: In the bush [επι του βατου], refers to a particular section in the Pentateuch, Exodus 3:2-6.
The Jews were accustomed to designate portions of scripture by the most noteworthy thing contained in them.
The article refers to it as something familiar.
Archibald T. Robertson: In the place concerning the Bush (επ του βατου). This technical use of επ is good Greek, in the matter of, in the passage about, the Bush.
Βατος is masculine here, feminine in Luke 20:37.
The reference is to Exodus 3:3-6 (in the book of Moses, εν τη βιβλω).
John Gill: And as touching the dead, that they rise... have ye not read in the book of Moses..."
The book of Exodus is particularly intended; for the passage referred to is in Exodus 3:6...
Saying, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse contains a reference to the book of Moses and the place concerning the Bush. The commentary suggests that this refers specifically to Exodus 3:2-6, where God speaks to Moses from the burning bush. The use of the definite article indicates that this passage would have been familiar to the audience. It is noteworthy that the translation of in the bush could also mean at the bush, but based on the structure of the verse, it is more likely referring to the section of Moses' history relating to the burning bush. This passage is significant because it proclaims God as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

The mention of the book of Moses and the place concerning the Bush in this verse allude to the well-known account of God speaking to Moses from the burning bush in Exodus 3:2-6. The use of the definite article suggests the familiarity of this incident to the audience. The translation of the phrase in the bush can also mean at the bush, but considering the structure of the verse, it likely refers to the section of Moses' history recounting the burning bush. This passage importantly identifies God as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

This passage is significant as it declares God as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
